The EFs seem to meet the requirements of a biological adaptation, being an improbable complex design for a purpose that exists universally in humans. Discovering the adaptive problems that the EFs evolved to solve offers an invaluable research agenda for neuropsychology lest that agenda be resolved first by other scientific disciplines. Some adaptive problems that the EFs may have evolved to solve are then considered, among them being social exchange, imitation and vicarious learning as types of experiential theft, and mimetic skill and gestural communication. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

column3: El habla analizada desde la perspectiva de Ribes y Lopez: desarrollo horizontal
column4: Mares G C; Rueda E P
column6: Discusses the development of linguistic behavior from the standpoint of Mexican behaviorists E. Ribes and F. Lopez, as stated in their book, 'Theory of behavior: field-and parametric analysis' (1985). In it, the authors develop the concept of horizontal development at the referential level. The Ribes and Lopez model of linguistic behavior incorporates some of Vygotsky's original ideas on the higher psychological processes (1979). Topics addressed, structured around speaking-writing relationships, include the development of verbal language from nonverbal (e.g., gestural) communication; results of experimental studies with children (no demographics given) on linguistic behavior. These studies involved reading texts and relating their contents to others. Skinner's categories of verbal behavior (1957) are also discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

column3: Family process and individual evolution
column6: Listening is fundamental to the analyst's role. Listening means accepting the patient's communication and giving meaning to the words that are said. The listening attitude fosters engagement in the encounter between patient and therapist and facilitates the emergence of transference. It creates conditions that make it possible to stage and unravel the unconscious web of fantasies underlying the emotional pain and the symptoms that prompt the patient to seek help. Listening is also fundamental to the family therapist's role, but since the patient is now a group of people, there are some additional aspects to the listening. In work with couples and families, much of the listening attitude is focused on the visuals. Body language and gestures deserve particular attention. The nonverbal aspects intertwine with the verbal exchanges to lend more, or less, congruity to what is being said and to establish alliances or conflicts which trigger intense feelings. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2019 APA, all rights reserved)

column3: Social games between bonobos and humans: Evidence for shared intentionality?
column6: Triadic social games are interesting from a cognitive perspective because they require a high degree of mutual social awareness. They consist of two agents incorporating an object in turn-taking sequences and require individuals to coordinate their attention to the task, the object, and to one another. Social games are observed commonly in domesticated dogs interacting with humans, but they have received only little empirical attention in nonhuman primates. Here, we report observations of bonobos (Pan paniscus) engaging in social games with a human playmate. Our behavioral analyses revealed that the bonobos behaved in many ways similar to human children during these games. They were interested in the joint activity, rather than the play objects themselves, and used communicative gestures to encourage reluctant partners to perform their role, suggesting rudimentary understanding of others' intentions. Our observations thus may imply that shared intentionality, the ability to understand and shares intention with other individuals, has emerged in the primate lineage before the origins of hominids. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

column3: Apraxia
column6: Apraxias are deficits of higher motor behaviour that are not primarily caused by elementary deficits of the sensorimotor system, communication problems, or dementia. The patients present with deficits in imitating meaningful or meaningless gestures, purposeful use of objects, or dexterity. The different forms of apraxia originate from lesions of different levels/structures of the motor system, reflecting its complexity. Apraxias are caused by deficits in motor programmes generated in the frontal motor areas (executive apraxias, e.g. limb-kinetic apraxia), in the modality-specific higher sensorimotor control (unimodal apraxias, e.g. tactile apraxia, optic apraxia), or at the highest level of motor planning and motor conception (polymodal apraxias, i.e. ideomotor and ideational apraxias). Polymodal apraxias typically result from left hemisphere lesions and are therefore often, but not necessarily, observed in combination with aphasia. The different types of apraxia differentially affect the activities of daily living and hence show marked differences in the prognosis of recovery and the need of physiotherapeutic treatment. Therefore, diagnosis and appropriate treatment of the different forms of apraxia is of foremost clinical importance. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2019 APA, all rights reserved)

column3: The process of remembering: Recovery and discovery
column6: Experiences of gradually recovering lost memories may shed some light on the cognitive mechanism underlying remembering. We (1) easily remember the external frame (the context) of the lost memory; (2) experience the emergence of its internal frame (category or genre); (3) recall its configuration, its rhythmic skeleton or its dynamic structure; (4) and even sketch it by a gesture; (5) recall our evaluation of the person or our impression of the event we cannot remember; (6) find the central object may emerge in a disguised (symbolic) form; (7) find the abortive first attempt to reconstruct the lost memory may contain an unconscious interpretation of the hidden event or the forgotten dream. Gradual remembering follows on the whole the path of verbal evolution. Trying to recapture lost memories we are compelled to make use of preverbal forms of mental elaboration and expression (visual thinking, gesture language, symbols). At the same time, recovery of lost memories has much in common with the procedure of scientific discovery. Discovery could be considered as a paradoxical form of remembering: recovering the unknown. Scientific metaphors uncover ('remember') preconscious and unconscious knowledge. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2018 APA, all rights reserved)

column3: Searching for language: Process, not product
column6: Discusses the contributions of W. C. Stokoe to the understanding of American Sign Language (ASL) as a language. The study of the signed language of deaf people can tell us about the nature of language, and from this work Stokoe developed an account of the gestural theory of language. The perspective that Stokoe adopted in his approach to the study of ASL and language in general is presented in three of his papers�'Where Should We Look for Language?', 'Sign Language versus Spoken Language', and 'Semantic Phonology'. The present author suggests that Stokoe's contributions in the area of semantic phonology are his most significant in that it captures the essence of his view of the structure of signed languages, but also of his argument for the gestural origin of language. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2019 APA, all rights reserved)

column3: The chameleon effect as social glue: Evidence for the evolutionary significance of nonconscious mimicry
column4: Lakin J; Jefferis V; Cheng C; Chartrand T
column6: The 'chameleon effect' refers to the tendency to adopt the postures, gestures, and mannerisms of interaction partners (Chartrand & Bargh, 1999). This type of mimicry occurs outside of conscious awareness, and without any intent to mimic or imitate. Empirical evidence suggests a bi-directional relationship between nonconscious mimicry on the one hand, and liking, rapport, and affiliation on the other. That is, nonconscious mimicry creates affiliation, and affiliation can be expressed through nonconscious mimicry. We argue that mimicry played an important role in human evolution. Initially, mimicry may have had survival value by helping humans communicate. We propose that the purpose of mimicry has now evolved to serve a social function. Nonconscious behavioral mimicry increases affiliation, which serves to foster relationships with others. We review current research in light of this proposed framework and suggest future areas of research. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

column3: Étude empirique de l'usage du geste et de la parole en situation de communication homme-machine
column4: Carbonell N; Valot C; Mignot C; Dauchy P
column6: Describes a prospective ergonomic study of how computer users will use unconstrained speech and gestures for interacting with standard computer applications. A realistic simulation of an interaction system, using the Wizard of Oz experimental paradigm was designed. Eight subjects performed various design tasks, using this simulated user interface during 3 weekly sessions. Analysis of the audiovisual protocols suggests great interindividual differences in styles of expression and strategies for combining speech with gestures. Styles of expression can be divided according to the nature of the relationships between the Ss and the system: communication with a machine interlocutor or manipulation of a graphical representation of the application. After a short initial adaptation phase, confined to the 1st scenario or to the 1st session, the styles of most Ss did not evolve. A few instances of later evolution were observed which point to interindividual differences relating to the capability of transferring competencies acquired in the context of human communication to a human�computer interaction environment. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

column3: Onset of voluntary communication: Smiling looks to mother
column6: Playing infants often direct smiling looks toward social partners. In some cases the smile begins before the look, so it cannot be a response to the sight or behavior of the social partner. In this study we asked whether smiles that anticipate social contact are used by 8- to 12-month-old infants as voluntary social signals. Eighty infants�20 at each of 8, 9, 10, and 12 mo of age�completed 5 tasks. The tasks assessed anticipatory smiling during toy play, means-end understanding (2 tasks), intentional communication via gesture and vocalizations, and memory for mother's location. Across all ages, anticipatory smiling was strongly predicted by intentional gestural and vocal communication and by means-end understanding. The findings are discussed in terms of the nature and origins of infants' voluntary communications. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

column3: Preconditions for the evolution of protolanguages
column6: Argues that hominids could not have evolved a capacity for 'protolanguage' without meeting at least 2 preconditions. The first is the prior evolution of a more powerful central motor capacity that gave hominids a degree of voluntary movement control that does not exist in any other species. This new motor-modelling skill, or 'mimesis,' allowed them to vary and elaborate upon the entire voluntary motor repertoire of the primate line. However, their communication use at this preliminary stage was probably restricted to action-metaphor, mime, and rudimentary gesture. The second precondition is the evolution of a more abstract capacity for expressive modelling, one that did not rely entirely on perceptual metaphor as the carrier of conventional meaning. In evolution, this second step provided the cognitive mechanism needed to construct the other side of the lexical entry, or lemma, and elevated the morphological inventiveness of hominids to a truly linguistic level. This innovation, probably first found in nascent form in early sapients, would have triggered the structural basis for evolving a capacity for lexical invention and the first protolanguages. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2019 APA, all rights reserved)

column3: Do children with autism understand imitation as intentional interaction?
column6: Synchronic imitation generates a unique phenomenon with multiple outcomes: seeing one's intentions acted through the behaviour of the other. In the past we have shown that imitation and imitation recognition allow preverbal infants to find common topics based on similar actions, and to take conversational turns by alternating the roles of imitator and model. Therefore the gap between recognizing actions and coding messages with communicative intent is not as enormous as it looks at first glance: Understanding the other's intentional actions is prepared by the use of the imitative system, via the action recognition mechanism. In this paper, we review earlier results with typical preverbal children and stress the importance of imitation in the sociocognitive development of nonverbal children with autism. Using a design which allows us to evaluate spontaneous imitation, we have found that even very low-functioning children with autism mostly produce spontaneous imitations in socially embedded situations. The imitations produced are simple gestural matching or imitations of familiar or novel actions that are goal-directed and involve affordant or non-affordant objects. They are a good predictor of social capacities. They enhance attention to persons and expectancies for social contingencies. Repeated imitative sessions improve imitation, recognition of being imitated, and nonverbal communication. Through being imitated low-functioning children with autism start understanding that they can be at the origin of intentional actions of others. This was shown through the use of a revisited version of the Still Face paradigm consisting in a still episode of a stranger followed by an imitative interaction initiated by the stranger and ending with a second still face: all children reacted to the second still face as a violation of intentional exchanges, while they had no protest during the first. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2017 APA, all rights reserved)

column3: The fatal smirk: Insider accounts of organizational change processes in a police organization
column4: Jacobs G; Keegan A; Christe-Zeyse J; Seeberg I; Runde B
column6: Purpose: The key to success and failure in change projects may lie not in groundbreaking events or heroic gestures but in the many seemingly meaningless acts and events that occur throughout all change projects. In order to gain a better understanding of factors leading to success in change projects, the purpose of this paper is to examine insider accounts of successful and unsuccessful change projects in a non-business public context, namely the German police. Design/methodology/approach: The research can be located in the exploratory, inductive research tradition and consistent with that we used in-depth semi-structured interviews to elicit the views of 92 high potential future managers as to what constitutes a(n) (un)successful project, and what factors lead to (un)successful project outcomes. Findings: The qualitative approach adopted allows for the tracing of a range social behavioural issues identified by members of the organization as criteria to evaluate the success of projects-commitment of peers and superiors, satisfaction of members with the outcome. Identifying factors leading to project success, participants identified the following-clear communication of both positive and potentially negative outcomes, commitment of leaders, and changes in work conditions resulting from the project. Research limitations/implications: Social and behavioural aspects of change projects, which are often relegated to a secondary position behind managerial and technical aspects, should be taken into account more often in (research on) change management projects. Originality/value: The findings are based on research that explicitly integrates the mundane aspects, the daily mistakes and the routine obstacles facing those involved in change projects and suggests the value of incorporating such issues in (research on) change management projects given the spread of projects from a traditional engineering context to a variety of different contexts including, increasingly, non-profit and governmental organizations. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2017 APA, all rights reserved)

column3: The shadow of your smile: Intrusion or engulfment
column6: The author's interest in infant observation studies grew from her clinical work with several adult patients who suffer from a chronic awareness of disconnection, frequent lapses into states of confusion, and an acute sense of feeling lost and unbounded. They seem to have no language for these experiences and have difficulty associating these phenomena with memories or current events, which suggests that the origins of their catastrophic anxiety and disorganization are preverbal. Observing infants, studying the mother-infant relationship, and reading the works of Meltzer, Rosenfeld, Winnicott, and eventually Bick helped the author to attend more carefully to nonverbal messages and the spontaneous gestures through which unconscious anxiety finds expression in adult psychotherapy patients. This chapter illustrates how the author has integrated her understanding from infant observation with her clinical work. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

column3: Hand, mouth and brain: The dynamic emergence of speech and gesture
column6: The notion that the mind arises from having a body that interacts with the environment (embodiment) stands in contrast to the prevailing cognitivist view which uses a computer metaphor to describe the structure of the mind: that thought is the product of abstract mental symbols and the rules by which they are mentally manipulated. This paper examines the embodiment of one foundational aspect of human cognition, language, through its bodily association with the gestures that accompany its expression in speech. The authors propose that speech and gesture have their developmental origins in early hand�mouth linkages. The initial sensorimotor linkages of these systems form the bases for their later cognitive interdependence. The authors defend their proposition with neurophysiological data demonstrating the close link between language and movement. The motor actions of hand and mouth are present from birth and evolve in a mutually interactive fashion during the first year of life. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2017 APA, all rights reserved)

column3: Cerebral asymmetry: Motoring on
column6: I argue that the phylogenetic and neurobiological bases for cerebral asymmetry in humans are likely to be found in motor systems rather than in perceptual systems. Current genetic models of human laterality suggest that a 'dextral' allele might be responsible for right-handedness and left-cerebral dominance for speech in the majority of humans. The linking of handedness with language lateralization might reflect the early evolution of language as predominantly a system of manual gestures, perhaps switching to a mainly vocal system only with the emergence of Homo sapiens. So-called 'mirror neurons' in the prefrontal cortex of the monkey, which fire both when the animal makes a grasping response and when it sees the same response performed by others, might be part of a circuit that is the precursor to language circuits in the brain. This circuit appears to be bilateral in monkeys, but left-hemispheric in humans. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2019 APA, all rights reserved)

column3: Recent, new, and forthcoming books on gesture and related topics
column6: Presents a catalogue of recent and forthcoming books for review on gesture and related topics. These include, 'Gestures and looks in medieval narrative,' by J.A. Burrrow; 'Gestures: Essays in ancient history,' edited by G.W. Bakewell and J.P. Sichinger; 'From hand to mouth: The origins of language,' by M.C. Corballis; 'Anglo-Saxon gestures and the Roman stag,' by C.R. Dodwell; 'The resiliance of language. What gesture creation in deaf children can tell us about how all children learn language (Essays in Developmental Psychology),' by Susan Goldin-Meadow; 'Grammar, gesture and meaning in American Sign Language,' by S.K. Liddell; 'Non-conscious movements. From mystical messages to facilitated communication,' by H.H. Spitz; 'Sterne's whimsical theatres of language: Orality, gesture, literacy. (Studies in Early Modern English Literature.),' by A. Tadie; 'The hand. How its use shapes the brain, language and human culture,' by F. Wilson etc. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

column3: Coherence in children's speech perception
column6: This study was originally undertaken to examine whether children would show the same patter of perceptual coherence for speech that adults showed in studies by H. Fitch et al (1980) and C. T. Best (1981). For this study stimuli was used that consisted of an [s] noise followed by a silent interval (as appropriate for a stop closure) and a vocalic portion. The results showed a strong coherence of separate acoustic cues in the speech perception of young children. An important development task facing young children is learning how to produce the articulatory gestures required of their native languages, and so these gestures are extremely relevant ecologically. Learning to strip off the individual acoustic properties is a perceptual skill that may only be required later. Thus, children do not discover phonetic coherence; instead, they learn to overcome it when necessary. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

column3: Mapping the range of information contained in the iconic hand gestures that accompany spontaneous speech
column6: Tested D. McNeill's (1985) theory that the iconic gestures that accompany speech in everyday talk convey critical information in interpersonal communication. Using a structured interview to measure the amount of information respondents received from clause-length clips of a cartoon story, the authors discovered that when respondents (all undergraduates) could see the iconic gestures as well as hear the speech, they received significantly more accurate information about those aspects of the original story depicted in the clips than with speech alone. Only with respect to certain semantic categories, namely, the relative position and the size of objects, the beneficial effect of gestural communication was significant. It was then considered in detail how specific attributes of actions and of objects are communicated via the iconic representation within individual gestures. Lastly, the implications of these findings for models of human communication in this area are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

column3: Read My Lips: Asymmetries in the Visual Expression and Perception of Speech Revealed Through the McGurk Effect
column4: Nicholls M; Searle D; Bradshaw J
column6: It is well known that the right side of the mouth moves more than the left during speech, but little is known about how this asymmetry affects lipreading. We investigated asymmetries in the visual expression and perception of speech using the McGurk effect--an illusion in which incongruent lip movements cause listeners to misreport sounds. Thirty right-handed participants watched film clips in which the left, the right, or neither side of the mouth was covered. The McGurk effect was attenuated when the right side of the mouth was covered, demonstrating that this side is more important to lipreading than is the left side of the mouth. Mirror-reversed images tested whether the asymmetry was the result of an observer bias toward the left hemispace. The McGurk effect was stronger in the normal than in the mirror orientation when the mouth was fully visible. Thus, observers attend more to what they think is the right side of the speaker's mouth. Asymmetries in mouth movements may reflect the gestural origins of language, which are also right lateralized. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

column3: Le jeu de transformation dans l'id�ogramme
column6: Ideographic writing, according to its principles of organization, is an analogical model for conceiving the construction of the human psyche. Languages, gesture, bodily attitudes, and sensory elements are the diverse aspects of figures of images and contribute to the dynamic and economic construction of intersubjectivity. The movement of the body contained in an ideogram inscribes identificatory processes in writing. The different components of an ideogram each occupy a place in the construction of the Ego and the Self. These transformations inside an ideogram portray the question of origins, of the difference between generations, of the sexes. The figures of images regroup or disperse themselves, like the dreamwork nourishing living breath, which is what I call the human being's animated being (anim�). The proximity between the approach of a clinical understanding of certain ideograms and formal signifiers such as described by Didier Anzieu, allow us to construct a representative model of the malleability of psychic conflictuality and to represent the dynamics of the processes of the visual unconscious. One can 'see' the transformations, folds and 'unfolds' of the economic dimension and dynamic position on considering formal signifiers and primary processes. Ideograms are constructed as a process of psychisation via the 'play' of transformation, from visual matter to psychic matter. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

column3: Could the future taste purple? Reclaiming mind, body and cognition
column6: This reprinted article originally appeared in Journal of Consciousness Studies, 1999, Vol 6(11�12), 41�60. (The following abstract of the original article appeared in record [rid]2000-13894-003[/rid].) This article examines the primacy of real-world bodily experience for understanding the human mind. The peculiarities of the living human brain and body, and the bodily experiences they sustain, are essential ingredients of human sense-making and conceptual systems. Conceptual systems are created, brought forth, understood, and sustained through very specific cognitive mechanisms ultimately grounded in bodily experience. They don't have a transcendental abstract logic independent of the species-specific bodily features. To defend this position, the author focuses on a case study: the fundamental concept of time flow. Using tools of cognitive linguistics, this concept is analyzed as it is manifested naturally in everyday language. There is a precise conceptual metaphor (mapping) whose inferential structure gives an account of a huge variety of linguistic expressions, semantic contents, and unconscious spontaneous gestures: Time Events Are Things In Space. This mechanism allows us to unconsciously, effortlessly, and precisely understand (and make inferences with) expressions such� (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

column3: De la emoción al espíritu metafórico. Semiosis e intersubjetividad en el desarrollo humano
column6: This paper deals with the developmental semiotic theory put forward by Angel Rivi�re. First, Rivier�'s most original proposal is presented: a semiotic creation mechanism--known as suspension--which encompasses landmark developmental sign formations, namely: emotional expressions, first deictic gestures, enactive symbols, pretend play, and metaphorical comprehension. Then specific assumptions of the Semiotic Suspension Theory are discussed and related to crucial subject areas in research on semiotic processes, such as: the link between semiosis and intersubjectivity; the relation between communication, cognition, and semiosis; the role of both object and instrumental action in sign formation as well as in the unfolding of mentalistic abilities, among others. Finally, a possible extension of the theory is proposed, including a new suspension source and a complementary way of understanding the emotional world and its consequences. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2019 APA, all rights reserved)

column3: The question of chimpanzee culture
column6: address the question of chimpanzee culture in 3 ways / review recent research on the types of social learning that chimpanzees and human children employ in 2 domains of particular importance to discussions of chimpanzee culture: tool use and communicatory gesturing / attempt to clarify some of the issues involved in the study of chimpanzee social learning and cultural [and behavioral] traditions through a brief look at research using captive chimpanzees raised in humanlike cultural environments / identify some key characteristics of human cultural traditions and ask if chimpanzee behavioral traditions display these same characteristics  tool use / gestural communication / social cognition and the role of human interaction / human and chimpanzee behavioral traditions / the evolution of culture (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

column3: Le dessin, mieux comprendre pour mieux intervenir
column6: Parce qu'il a sur les autres arts d'expression �comme le jeu symboliquc ou le langage �l'avantage de laisser une trace, le dessin se pr�te spontan�ment � l'cxamcn. L'apprenti-peintre peut done s'auto-examiner pour am�liorer ses productions graphiques. Ce va-et-vient constant entre cr�ation et r�vision lui permet de s'expliquer le monde et de s'y d�couvrir. Poser un regard sur ces productions enfantines, c'est tenter de saisir non seulement la mani�re dont l'enfant appr�hende le monde mais aussi la mani�re dont elle1 g�re les �motions qui en r�sultent. En dessinant, l'enfant traduit non seulement sa compr�hension du monde et des choses mais elle expose aussi ses souffrances, ses angoisses et ses d�sespoirs. Cet article veut d'abord retracer l'�volution d�veloppementale des sch�mes cognitifs et affectifs exprim�s par les dessins pour ensuite proposer, � l'aide d'exemples tir�s de la pratique, des pistes d'accompagnement. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

column3: Body politics and beyond
column6: This reprinted chapter originally appeared in Body Politics: Power, Sex, and Nonverbal Communication (1977). It discusses relationships among gender, gesture, and power. The overwhelming bulk of sex-differentiated behavior is learned, and is developed to display otherwise unobtrusive differences. The same behaviors exhibited by a superior to a subordinate are those typically exhibited by males to females; females exhibit to males the behaviors typical of a subordinate to a superior. Power is particularly illuminated in relationships between males and females, including those often considered sexually based. Power and sexuality are often confused in society. Females can stop smiling unless they're happy, lowering or averting their eyes when stared at, and getting out of males' way in public. They can start staring people in the eye, addressing people by their first names, and being more relaxed in demeanor. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

column3: Neurobehavioral disorders
column6: Persons who live in the US but were born in Central or South America, along with their descendants who live with them, can suffer from the same neurological disorders as non-Hispanics living in the US. The variation is found in the severity of incidence and especially how they cope with their illness in an environment that - in regards to language, social organization, cultural memory, interests, and motivations - is different from their own. Therefore, the clinical manifestations of the neurological disorders are metasymptoms that should not misinterpreted. The symptoms and complaints shown by these patients should be understood in their context; more importantly, some of the behavioral gestures, or the way they express their feelings, are not symptoms, but references to their cultural origin. A table shows the values to be considered when carrying out any type of neuropsychological intervention with ethnic minorities in a multicultural society. The differences of culture and the design of the mental health services cause Hispanics to under-use health services. Diagnosis and treatment should be addressed by competent, specialized, Spanish-speaking doctors, who are well trained in the Hispanic culture. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2019 APA, all rights reserved)

column3: Comunicacion no verbal en el retiro esquizoide: Un caso clinico
column6: Illustrates with the clinical case of a schizoid patient the defense mechanism of schizoid withdrawal that gives the analyst the feeling that the patient is unapproachable and impenetrable. In the analytic session, the patient's withdrawal manifested itself in the form of drowsiness, which frequently turned into sleep. This was frustrating for the analyst when she was unable to tell whether the patient listened to what she was saying. She attributed her patient's schizoid withdrawal to his use of the primitive mechanism of ego splitting. The analyst's interpretive approach, based on her countertransference and on the observation of the patient's gestures and onomatopoeias, allowed for evolution of the analytic process. The integrating interpretation of these split aspects must be channelled toward repairing the egoic functions. During the last year of analysis, the patient overcame his tendency to fall asleep at the sessions, and the possibility of genuine emotional communication improved. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

column3: On the evolution of language and generativity
column6: The evolution of language began 2 million yrs ago beginning as a system of manual gestures (in prehominid apes) progressing to a predominantly vocal mode with the emergence of Homo sapiens sapiens. This coincides with the gradual increase in brain size and the gradual prolongation of childhood. It was during this period that stone tool cultures developed, although they did not display the generativity and open endedness of contemporary manufacture. The emergence of vocal language freed the hands for the further development of manufacture and other manual pursuits. The evolutionary explosion heralded the application of generative principles that appeared 1st in the context of language and then in other kinds of activity. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

column3: The gestural repertoire and its evolution over the second year
column4: Blake J; McConnell S; Horton G; Benson N
column6: To study the evolution of communicative gestures in a natural context over the second year, the entire repertoire of communicative gestures was documented in a longitudinal, observational study of 10 infants (aged 9�22 mo). Early in the second year, giving as a request to do something with an object increased, while emotive gestures decreased. Later in the second year, pointing gestures increased, while protest gestures tended to decrease. Combining gestures with vocalization tended to increase only for protest gestures later in the second year. Eye contact showed a small but continuous increase in coordination with gestures over the second year, particularly with comment, request, and emotive gestures. These findings indicate an increasing use of the parent as an agent of the informative function in non-verbal communication during this period of transition to verbal communication. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

column3: Intesensory redundancy and 7-month-old infants' memory for arbitary syllable�object relations
column4: Gogate Lakshmi J; Bahrick Lorraine E
column6: This article presents 2 experiments to address infants' memory for learned arbitrary syllable�object relations while temporal synchrony is present during habituation. In Exp 1, infants remembered the syllable�object relations after 10 min, only when temporal synchrony between vocalizations and moving objects was provided during learning. In Exp 2, 7-mo-olds were habituated to the same syllable�object pairs in the presence of temporal synchrony and tested for memory after 4 days. Once again, infants learned and showed emerging memory for the syllable�object relations 4 days after original learning under the temporally synchronous condition. These findings are consistent with the view that prior to symbolic development, infants learn and remember word�object relations by perceiving redundant information in the vocal and gestural communication of adults. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

column3: Language development from an evolutionary perspective
column6: evaluates language development from the viewpoint of Darwinian and modern evolutionary theory / conceptualizes language development as 'a sort of postnatal embryology' / argues that the neural substrate for language was shaped during phylogeny and language performance continues that shaping as the child uses language  main thesis for elucidating the way language develops is that: 'language function thus determines language form, and form is viewed as an a posteriori description of rather than an a priori prescription for development' / employs the general principles that emerge from the evolutionary biology model as a framework within which to explicate the emergence of phonetic segments / discusses the role of perception and analyzes the mechanisms involved in production (integration and differentiation) as these contribute to the acquisition of language / details how gestures become integrated in a manner that leads to the expression of phonemes (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

column3: Conversational moves and conversational styles of adult cochlear-implant users
column6: Determined whether adults with significant hearing impairments (HIs) typically recognize the occurrence of a communication breakdown, and if so, whether they are usually able to rectify the breakdowns. Nine adult cochlear-implant users (aged 28�77 yrs) engaged in spontaneous conversation with naive communication partners who did not know about their HIs. The interactions were videotaped, orthographically transcribed, and coded. Ss usually recognized when they did not understand a message and then used repair strategies. Most commonly, they asked 'what?' or 'huh?', or used a nonverbal body gesture. Communication partners' most common response to these nonspecific repair strategies was a verbatim repetition of the original message. A model of 3 conversational styles (interactive, passive, and aggressive) is described. Persons with HI might display a constellation of behaviors typical of 1 or more of these styles. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

column3: A comprehensive theory of representation for mathematics education
column6: Representation is a difficult concept. Behaviorists wanted to get rid of it; many researchers prefer other terms like 'conception' or 'reasoning' or even 'encoding'; and many cognitive science researchers have tried to avoid the problem by reducing thinking to production rules. The author discusses at least two reasons for considering representation as an important subject for scientific study. The first is that we all experience representation as a stream of internal images, gestures and words. The second is that the words and symbols we use to communicate do not refer directly to reality but to represented entities: objects, properties, relationships, processes, actions, and constructs, about which there is no automatic agreement between two persons. It is the purpose of this paper to analyse this problem, and to try to connect it with an original analysis of the role of action in representation. The issue is important for mathematics education and even for the epistemology of mathematics, as mathematical concepts have their first roots in the action on, and in the representation of, the physical and social world; even though there may be a great distance today between that pragmatical and empirical source, and the sophisticated concepts of contemporary mathematics. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

column3: Incidence du cognitific sur les processus de symbolisation: leur �volutin dan la cure
column6: Reports 1 yr of therapy with a male child whose lack of language is related both to cognitive deficiencies and psychological conflicts. Main points examined include (a) the relationship between his deficiencies and conflicts, and (b) the place of gesture in the symbolic system, and factors of evolution. (French, English & Spanish abstracts) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

column3: Language and gesture in late talkers: A 1-year follow-up
column4: Thal D J; Tobias S; Morrison D
column6: Reports a 1-yr follow-up of relationships between language and symbolic gesture in 10 children (aged 18�29 mo) with delayed onset of early lexical skills (D. Thal and E. Bates; see record [rid]1988-36156-001[/rid]). Original data were reevaluated in light of new knowledge about which late talkers continued to be significantly delayed 1 yr later (truly delayed) and which ones had 'caught up' (late bloomers). All 4 Ss who were truly delayed at follow-up had been delayed in language comprehension at the 1st visit, but the 6 late bloomers had been at the same level as their age-matched controls. Truly delayed late talkers had been significantly poorer on all of the gesture tasks than late talkers who caught up. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2017 APA, all rights reserved)

column3: Ontogeny of phonetic gestures: Speech production
column6: A commentary by Michael Studdert-Kennedy follows this chapter. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

column3: The understanding of Chinese and Kurdish emblematic gestures by Dutch subjects
column4: Poortinga Y; Schoots N; Van de Koppel J
column6: Emblematic gestures as a form of nonverbal communication were elicited from young men from Kurdistan, China, and the Netherlands (4 Ss from each country). A distinction was drawn between referential and conventional emblems. For each culture, 25 emblems were selected that had an unambiguous meaning within the culture in which they originated. The study investigated whether all gestures judged to be referential were present in the Netherlands in the opinion of a sample of Dutch Ss. Allowing for a margin of error in the classification of the gestures, this hypothesis could not be rejected. The specificity of meaning of conventional gestures was investigated for which none of the Ss in the 1st part of the study knew the correct meaning. Results indicate that codes can be entirely arbitrary, with no trace of a cross-culturally shared referential basis. Psychological universalism seems to give the best account of the findings. (French abstract) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

column3: Gestes et mimiques comme langage universel chez les th�oriciens du XIX�me si�cle
column6: Discusses the 19th-century origins of research on gestures and facial expressions as a universal language. Various 19th-century approaches for studying the universality of nonverbal behaviors are described, including the human�animal comparisons by C. Darwin (1872) and P. Gratiolet (1865). W. Wundt's (1900) psycholinguistic perspective, which replaces the focus on universality with an emphasis on natural and conventional signs and gestural syntax, is reviewed. (English abstract) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

column3: Early imitation within a functional framework: The importance of person identity, movement, and development
column4: Meltzoff A N; Moore M K
column6: (This reprinted article originally appeared in Infant Behavior and Development, 1992, Vol 15[4], 479�505. The following abstract of the original article appeared in PA, Vol 80:21255.) Investigated in 2 experiments facial imitation (FCI) in 32 infants (aged 6 wks) and 16 infants (aged 2�3 mo). Three findings emerged. Early imitation did not vary as a function of familiarity with the model; Ss imitated a stranger as well as their own mothers. Ss imitated both static facial postures and dynamic facial gestures. There was no disappearance of FCI in the 2�3 mo olds. A proposal was made about the social and psychological functions that early imitation (EI) served in Ss' encounters with people. Ss deployed imitation to enrich their understanding of persons and actions, and EI was used for communicative purposes. A theoretical bridge was formed between EI and the 'object concept.' One of the psychological functions that EI served was to identify people. Ss used the nonverbal behavior of people as an identifier of who they were and used imitation as a means of verifying this identity. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

column3: The development of communication: Wallon's framework and influence
column6: focuses on an analysis of H. Wallon's influence on European Francophone concepts, methods, and data in the realm of nonverbal and prelinguistic communication / delineate what has been tested, and what remains to be proved of what is still original and testable  the sociable infant / self�other differentiation / the basic role of gesture in expression and evocation (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2019 APA, all rights reserved)

column3: Using direct instruction to teach a nonvocal student with autism to read through discrimination training
column4: Ferris K; Fabrizio M A; Holtz T; Kosobutsky K
column6: Presents the case report of Spencer, a nonvocal, 9-year old boy with severe autism who communicates through his augmentative communication device and gestures. He has no intact speech and can imitate only a very small number of sounds accurately. Because Spencer lacked all of the required component speaking skills needed to benefit from direct instruction reading curricula, we created a modified instructional script that we based on the direct instruction curriculum Teach Your Child to Read in 100 Easy Lessons. In a 10-minute session, Spencer completed between one and six exercises from the curriculum and typically responded between 20 and 60 times per 10 minutes. The number of responses Spencer expressed during any given exercise was a minimum of x3 the number of required responses in the original teaching script, because of the need to present Spencer with a full range of correct and incorrect models. Now that we have evidence that discrimination training can be an effective tool to allow nonvocal students to access high-quality decoding. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

column3: Origin of language
column6: The word roots of various languages are discussed with reference to the theory that 'a great part of human speech originated in the speaking organs' unconscious imitation of the gestures of the human body, especially the hands.' The major consideration is given to those words regarded as representing primitive man's imitation of something round, vaulted, curved, or hollow and to the names of the parts of the human body which describe the form, shape, or activity of the part. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

column3: Form and function in early communication: Language and pointing gestures
column6: Contrasted pointing gestures of 11 verbally advanced 2-yr-olds with that of 11 less advanced peers to examine the relationships of gesture to language during the acquisition of each. Hypotheses specifying the replacement of gestural functions by speech as verbal skills improve, developmental correspondences between the 2 communicative domains, and the independence of language acquisition from nonverbal developments were drawn from evolutionary, structuralist, and nativist viewpoints, respectively. Both formal and functional aspects of each communicative skill were measured. Results indicate that formal and functional aspects of verbal and gestural skills were largely unrelated, particularly in the gestural domain. No evidence that language replaced gesture for communication in ontogeny was obtained. Correspondences between gesture and language occurred only between functional aspects of each. Findings suggest the independence of developing language from gestural advances. (31 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2017 APA, all rights reserved)

column3: K probleme proiskhozhleniya yazika
column6: The literature connected with various theories in regard to language formations is reviewed. Most of the theories do not satisfy the author, who analyzes them from a materialistic point of view. Finally the concepts of N. Y. Marr are taken up; he published his theory of the origin of language in 1926 in the Proceedings of the Oriental Institute of the Soviet Republics. Marr studied the language of the less known tribes of the Caucasus, which is extremely primitive and is still in the process of early formation. Language originates in the primitive society when man first begins to modify his environment; in other words, when he begins to work. The primitive man looks upon work as magic because he does not expect the results in profound changes in the individual. The whole organism, including the vocal apparatus, participates in the primitive production. Collective effort is always accompanied by the three original arts�dance, music and vocal speech. Previous to this in the history of evolution man used gestures as form of social intercourse. Vocal speech must have begun with the Stone Age, when man began to make implements. Language development goes parallel with the increase of collective, human activities. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

column3: Did throwing stones shape hominid brain evolution?
column6: Suggests that early hominid evolution may have involved an interaction between lateralization to left brain of rapid motor sequencing (e.g., right-handedness) and its selection via 1-handed throwing of stones at small prey. Since a more redundant sequencer should permit faster orchestration of muscles, faster (and hence longer range) throws could have selected for encephalization. Secondary uses of the enlarged sequencer may have included tool-sharpening and manual gestures. Because an oral�facial sequencing area just below motor strip forms the core of modern language cortex, there may have been a common origin of handedness and language in redundant sequencing circuits selected by throwing success. (51 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2017 APA, all rights reserved)

column3: The origin and development of language
column6: Vocal language is the means whereby words become a method of expression of ideas and feelings. The origin of language in the history of mankind is shrouded in the distant haze of antiquity. The thinkers of ancient Greece sought to find an answer to the question of its genesis. There is little doubt that vocal and sign language gained much in complexity as the evolution of a more complicated nervous system proceeded in man. Doubtless language began as a very simple series of grunts and gestures which were helpful in arousing meanings through their connections with the nervous engrams or traces of previous events. A cry of pain meant danger, a laugh meant pleasure, certain bodily attitudes meant caution or 'be on the alert' to those who previously had observed them. These cries and bodily attitudes ideationally aroused certain previous experiences which had been contiguous with them in the past. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

column3: The Biological and Social Significance of the Expression of the Emotions
column6: Speculative article starting with a classification of emotions on the basis of expression with emphasis on the secretions. The social and biological significance of these expressions are noted. It is argued that all this applies equally well to a theory of the origin of language. Language must be formed by the continuation of the evolution of the expression of the emotions from the biological to the social. The emotional mimicry empties itself more and more of its affective contents and becomes a mere symbol�the language of gestures. On the other hand, the emotional reactions specializing in cry, which itself became intelligent and more and more complicated, developed into spoken language. From Psych Bulletin 19:12:00910. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

column3: The social significance of language
column4: Krueger E T; Reckless Walter C
column6: Social psychology is not immediately concerned with the origin of language, since this scientific interest clearly falls within the province of philology. Neither is it directly concerned with the physiology or anatomy of human speech. On the other hand, it does have a vital interest in the relation of language and gesture to human nature, imagination, reflection, self-consciousness, and especially in the way in which the child learns to talk and takes over a vocabulary and the meaning of words and gestures. But before passing to the main part of this discussion, it is important to note the difference between animal gestures and human language and the relation of language to culture. Man is clearly distinguishable from the animal by his symbolic form of communication. Whether or not the cries, songs, and emotional expressions of animals really constitute a language, in the sense just mentioned, is very doubtful. Language and gestures of human beings, on the other hand, involve the transfer of ideas, meanings, memories. Whether language antedated culture in man's pre-history is a question which must, in the circumstances, be settled theoretically. The important point for social psychology and sociology is the active relationship of language to culture. Some means of symbolic communication, it appears, is necessary for the development of human nature. Reflection seems to be a peculiarly human trait. Whether animals actually reflect on experience and their own behavior is, in the light of recent research in animal psychology, very doubtful. A symbolic form of communication, enabling individuals to have a frame of reference for their behavior, really opens the door for the development of self-consciousness, which seems to be a socially acquired trait of human beings. Animals share consciousness with man, but it is doubtful whether they share self-consciousness with the human race. The balance of the chapter examines infant speech, linguistics, and language acquisition, emphasizing the social contexts. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

column3: Language development under atypical learning conditions: Replication and implications of a study of deaf children of hearing parents
column6: as in our previous work, this replication study focuses on three primary questions / whether the deaf children in the second sample use gestures to communicate in the same way as our original subjects did / can consistent patterns of production be found within each child's set of gestures / whether those structured regularities are language-like  second sample [consisted] of four deaf children of hearing parents, ranging in age from 1;4 to 3;1 at the first interview and residing in a different region of the United States  goal in this study is to show that the gesture systems developed by both my [author's] old and new deaf subjects without the benefit of a conventional language model, when described using the tools of the field of child language, contain the structural properties of the language systems developed by young children who have been exposed to conventional language models (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

column3: The patient, the mother, the therapist: An interactional triangle in the treatment of the autistic child
column6: Discusses the psychotherapy process of an autistic child from 31/2-6 yr. old. Based on the developmental history, and the clinical observations during psychotherapy, an attempt is made to present the patterns of communication and interaction as they developed from the original mother-child interaction through the development and changes in the child-therapist communication patterns. These changes were paralleled by changes in the mother-child interaction and in the mother-therapist interaction. The early unpredictable system of mother-child communication consisted of a mixture of aggression and rejection appearing at random. Through the initiation of psychotherapy, this reverberating pathological interaction changed to an interactional triangle between child-therapist, mother-child, and mother-therapist. Presently the child uses meaningful nonverbal communication, but does not use vocalization to convey messages. The therapy is continuing. The term of 'jargon communication' is proposed to define the global expressive disorder in autism. The distorted language (or the lack of it) and other pathological motor manifestations, representing a nonverbal gestural jargon, lead to the 'jargon communication.' (38 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2018 APA, all rights reserved)

column3: Language
column6: There are several theories of the origin of language, but they account for the particular sounds used rather than for the phenomenon of communication. The suggestion that the first language was a language of gestures conflicts with the fact that vocal expression occurs in animals below man. The experimental evidence for phonetic symbolism supports the theory that onomatopoeia may account for some of the actual sounds used in spoken language. More important is the demonstration of a relationship between language and thought; the forms of language determine certain modes of observation and interpretation. This may be seen not only in the animistic thinking of young children, but also in the complex speculations of philosophers. The content of a vocabulary reflects the interests of the corresponding culture, but does not justify any conclusions as to the intellectual capacity of a people. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

column3: Development of instincts--The expressive instinct
column6: This instinct belongs with the resultant and miscellaneous group because it owes its origin to various other instincts. Expression is a means of frightening enemies, and communicating with friends regarding food and danger, consequently it has been developed in the attainment of individual, parental, and social ends. In the lowest animals, expression, so far as there is any, is accomplished by means of feelers or antennae (notably in the case of ants), but in higher animals the chief means used are sounds. Most mammals and birds have from two or three to a dozen different calls which are appropriately responded to by others of their species. In man, the expressive instinct reaches its highest development because of his social nature and the perfectness of his vocal organs, and also because of the complexity of the mental states to be expressed. Instinctive emotional expression and expressive gestures are so effective that savages, without a word of artificial language in common, can communicate more accurately than any of the lower animals. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

column3: Relation of tone and gesture to words
column6: We have already seen that spoken language differs from the language of tone and gesture in being, as a system of signs, more purely conventional. This means that for semiotic purposes articulation is a higher product of mental evolution than either gesticulation or intonation. It also means that as an instrument of such evolution articulate speech is more efficient. The latter point is an important one, so I shall proceed to deal with it at some length. As noticed in a previous chapter, our system of coinage, bank-notes, and bills of sale is a more convenient system of signifying value of labour or of property, than is the more primitive and less conventional system of actually exchanging the labour or bartering the property; and our system of arithmetic is similarly more convenient for the purpose of calculation than is the more natural system of counting on the fingers. But not only are these more conventional systems more convenient; they are likewise conducive to a higher development of business transactions on the one hand, and of calculation on the other. In the absence of such an improved system of signs, it would be impossible to conduct as many or such intricate transactions and calculations as we do conduct. Similarly with speech as distinguished from gesture. Words, like gestures, are signs of thoughts and feelings; but in being more conventional they are more pure as signs, and so admit of being wrought up into a much more convenient or efficient system, while at the same time they become more constructive in their influence upon ideation. The great superiority of words over gestures in both these respects may most easily be shown by the use of a few examples. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

column3: Some prelinguistic aspects of language development
column6: Discusses prelinguistic aspects of language development in relation to the evolution of language function. The newborn infant engages and terminates visual, kinesthetic, oral, and sound reciprocity with the mother, thus providing the infant with a significant measure of control over reciprocal exchanges. The social smile, modulations thereof, and the face itself become organizers of meaningful vocalization, a focal point around which phonemes emerge from the mutuality of the mother�infant relationship. The evolution and meaning of the pointing gesture as it relates to language functioning and stages of separation�individuation are discussed. It is suggested that the child's capacity to evaluate the context of utterances in relation to dynamically integrated facial�vocal configurations with familiar caretakers provides the basis for the development of semantics and syntax in later language functioning. (3 p ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

column3: The transformation of sensorimotor morphemes into words: A case study of the development of 'more' and 'mine'
column6: Describes an evolving segment of communication during the course of transition of 1 child's total communication system from the sensorimotor or gestural level at 12 mo into the level of use of the adult words more and mine, and their associated multimorphemic utterances, at 24 mo. The descriptive analysis is based on detailed narrative records of the child's vocal and gestural communication, abstracted from videotape recordings of his behavior in 10 play sessions which included the presence of the mother, peers, other adults, and play materials. Results provide a case study of the evolutionary processes leading up to the acquisition of words and eventually sentences, illustrating the texture of one of the earliest developmental sequences. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

column3: Mental evolution and the social medium
column6: In the progress of social evolution new starts or variations occur, just as organic starts occur, and they are in like manner the results of new combinations between the conditions immanent in the individual and the coincident apt conditions of the social medium--the intrinsic and the influent conditions. Already have we seen how an individual develops a variation when he takes the tone of manner and feeling and thought of a particular sect of society in which he lives. That the social medium has been created for man by humanity, as the blood is formed by the tissues for the organism, is a fact which we cannot keep too clearly in mind when we are considering its character and influence. As soon as he enters it, he finds himself surrounded with the fruits of the long travail of humanity in the most easily assimilable forms: a language that embodies its social evolution; all the various appliances of the arts and sciences that have been tediously acquired in the succession of ages; commerce and its complicated monetary means for the interchange of commodities; the surface of the earth as it has been laboriously adapted lo his uses by countless generations of mankind; human beings of his own kind, each of whom has implicit in his nature the experiences of the race from its beginning, and so appeals, as well by the silent eloquence of look and gesture as by the articulate word, to the like implicit contents of his nature. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2019 APA, all rights reserved)

column3: Wundt e il linguaggio dei gesti
column6: In a chapter from V�lkerpsychologie, W. Wundt (1900) analyzed the language of gestures used among North American Indians, Neapolitans, Cistercian Monks, and deaf individuals. He then proposed a typology of gestures in terms of the relationship between gestures and their meanings. The present author reviews Wundt's ideas concerning gestures and compares them with recent works on the language of gesture and on American Sign Language. Some issues that are not clear in Wundt's work are discussed, e.g., word order in gestural sentences, iconicity and arbitrariness, and the origin of gestures from the expression of emotions. (24 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

column3: The emotions and conduct
column6: The author begins this chapter with a discussion of the emotions as sources of human quality, noting organic conditioning and the variety of expression. Emotions like irritability, anger, indignation, and lament are all examined, as are their functional service, and their points of inlet, central diffusion, and outlet in primary situations. The author then describes emotion as a spur to meet urgent situations, as the zest of experience, and as motive to conduct. The relation of emotions and sensibilities is noted. The author then describes the motor aspect of emotions and emotional regulation, particularly in regard to sex and food situations--what he calls the luxurious sensibilities and esthetic emotion--before he analyzes the intellectual expansion. After examining the primary emotions, the author analyzes fear as a primitive emotion. The expression of emotion is described, including facial and related miens and expression as incipient response, and the attitudes, situations, direction, and stages of emotional expression. Illustrations from animal responses are provided to illuminate the author's point. From this starting point, the author discusses the complexity of human emotion, the refinement of emotion and of its expression, facial language and its principles, mien and gesture, and the varied sources of facial expression. Also described are specialized expressions, differentiation and transfer, and natural and acquired expression, such as manner and restraint. The author then discusses emotion and its object, the role of instinct, and the complication and interplay of the emotions, such as attention interest and curiosity. The flexibility and evolution of emotions are then examined, in both presentative and representative stages. The emotional movement from pain to grief is analyzed, as is the intellectualization of emotions. Special bearings of the principle of transfer are discussed, including transfer in expression, emotional congeniality in transfer, and the evidence of language; gregariousness and sociability are used as examples. The author concludes by reiterating that emotion is central in human quality, again describing its sources and persistence. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2019 APA, all rights reserved)

column3: On talking or the communication of ideas and feelings by means of mainly audible symbols
column6: Sounds (clicks) made by babies are made by repetition of elements of the act of sucking. Babbles'� are not labels or pointers but merely gestures expressive of pleasure.' Language, even when used denotatively, retains its expressive quality. The evolution of the pronoun I shows that the use of the word parallels the development of the ego. In human and individual history, inhibition of the fundamental meaning of language occurs. Expression and engendering of archaic imagery are often frustrated when 'pure' verbal constructs are employed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

column3: Young children's coordination of gestural and linguistic reference
column4: Tomasello M; Anselmi D; Farrar M J
column6: Investigated the relationship between young children's linguistic and nonlinguistic communicative strategies. 23 children, 20�44 mo of age, served as Ss. In a naturalistic setting, an adult gave signs of noncomprehension (a contingent query) to each of the S's object references. The S's original linguistic reference and use of gestures were recorded and compared to his/her subsequent linguistic and gestural responses to the adult query. Results show that the Ss used gestures more often with pronouns than with nouns. Results imply that 2�3 yr old children are aware of the communicative principle that pronouns need gestures more than nouns and that the children are capable of coordinating their linguistic and nonlinguistic communicative strategies. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

column3: A cross-cultural study of the communication of extra-verbal meaning by gestures
column6: Conducted a study with 24 English and 24 Italian male college students. One member of each 4-member same-culture group was randomly assigned to be the encoder, the others to act as decoders. Encoders were asked to communicate 2-dimensional shapes to decoders, with and without the use of hand gestures, for materials of high and low verbal codability. Decoders drew what they thought the shapes were, and these were rated by English and Italian judges, for similarity to the originals. Higher accuracy scores were obtained by both the English and the Italians, when gestures were allowed, for materials of both high and low codability; but the effect of using gestures was greater for materials of low codability. Improvement in performance when gestures were allowed was greater for materials of low codability. Improvement in performance when gestures were allowed was greater for the Italians than for the English for both levels of codability. An analysis of the recorded verbal utterances has shown that the detriment in communication accuracy with the elimination of gestures cannot be attributed to disruption of speech performance; rather, changes in speech content occur, indicating an increased reliance on verbal means of conveying spatial information. It is concluded, nevertheless, that gestures convey this kind of semantic information more accurately, and evidence is provided for the gestures of the Italians communicating this information more effectively than those of the English. (French summary) (16 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

column3: Expressive movements
column6: As every gesture is wont to appear in association with the expression of countenance appropriate to it, when it has a language value, it seems advisable to treat together expressions and gestures which together form pantomime, and to separate the purely expressive muscular movements of the infant from its other movements, in our attempt to trace their origin. Of the expressive movements of the child I have especially considered, as to their origin, smiling and laughing, pouting and kissing, crying and wrinkling of the forehead, shaking the head and nodding, shrugging the shoulders, and begging with the hands, as well as pointing. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

column3: Overt symbolic behavior: I Gesture
column4: LaPiere R T; Farnsworth P R
column6: In this chapter the authors discuss the overt symbolic behavior of gesture. Topics include the functions of gesture; subtleties of gestural language; gestures and modern life; the social origin of gestural symbols; the lack of natural gestures; differences in gesture languages; the acquisition of gestural behavior; self-expression through gestures; limitations of gestures; and gestures of pain, discomfort, and pleasure. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2019 APA, all rights reserved)

column3: The sign language of deafmutes
column6: In three schools for deaf-mutes in Bengal, it was found that there had been developed very elaborate gesture languages. Some of the gestures had the same meaning from school to school, but most of them were of purely local significance. The languages were chiefly composed of symbols representative of some aspect or feature of the objects and events of their common experience, although in many cases the origin has been obscured by extension of meaning. Reveries and dreams sometimes have this gesture accompaniment, but it cannot be stated definitely whether or not the deaf-mutes think in these terms. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

column3: Questions pr�alables � une recherche psychanalytique sur le trait
column6: Considers early-childhood trace-drawings as manifestations of the infantile psyche on its way to separating from the maternal psyche. The infant's psychic evolution toward an ability to make a 'graphic gesture' begins at approximately 18 mo. The complex kinesthetic actions involved in these early graphic manifestations coincide with the infant's first locomotor attempts, rudimentary language use, and sphincter-muscle control. The infant realizes its separateness from its mother's body and unconsciously perceives its tracings on paper as traces left by the mother's moving away from her child. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

column3: The evolution of human communicative behavior
column6: evolutionary framework / behavioral homology  behavioral systems / communicative behavior / naturalistic and experimental studies of general complex behavior of the great apes / in non-human primates / brain damage and gestural abilities  peripheral structures / vocal tract / ear / neurological feature detectors  central control and processing systems (the central nervous system) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

column3: Language
column6: This chapter discusses the use of language in savage races. Topics covered in this chapter include, but are not limited to: gesture language; origin of language; root-words; onomatopoeia; nicknames; slang terms; savage languages; numerals; arithmetic; and the origins of the decimal system (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

column3: On the origin of concepts and roots
column6: The point at which we have now arrived is this: Taking language such as we find it and dissolving it into its constituent elements we can show that both dictionary and grammar are made up of nothing but--1. Predicative Roots, definite in sound, and expressive of general concepts; 2. Demonstrative Elements, likewise definite in sound, but not conceptual in meaning. Leaving the demonstrative elements as unexplained, except as possible remnants of an early gesture language in which objects are simply pointed at, but not conceived or described, we now turn to the most important of all questions, viz. How did Concepts arise, those very concepts which are expressed by our predicative roots? The question of the origin of concepts, or of the origin of true relation between the singular and the general, is the cardinal question of all philosophy. Feuerbach does not exaggerate when he writes, 'The question as to the relation of the species to the individual is the most important and at the same time the most difficult question of human knowledge and philosophy.' Let us also remember that in analyzing language we found that its constituent elements were predicative and demonstrative roots. This is a fact, not an hypothesis, and it shows us that all words, so far from being, as Berkeley supposed, the means of forming general ideas, presuppose their existence in the shape of roots. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

column3: Learning Theory and Language Learning: The Problem of 'Imitation'
column6: The phenomenon of mediation provides a bridge or tradition from relatively simple principles that govern animal behavior to the more elaborate 'intellectual' or 'symbolic' processes found in humans. Language and learning have a curiously interactive, or reciprocal, relationship: language is itself learned; but, once learned, it then importantly facilitates and guides further learning. These two aspects of the relationship seem to be sufficiently important and sufficiently different to warrant separate chapters, the present one being devoted to language learning and the following one to learning through language. The systematic analysis of language learning, we shall find, generates a surprisingly satisfactory conception of imitative behavior in general, and one that articulates easily and meaningfully with the concept of 'habit' as it emerges in revised two-factor learning theory. After describing the understanding and use of words, the author turns to word learning and other instances of habit formation. The 'Autism' theory of word learning is restated and extended, then applied clinically. The author outlines the origin of language, with special reference to gesturing, comparing the Bow-Wow (onomatopoetic) theory and the Autism theory of learning. The importance of imitation in language learning is described among many earlier theorists, as is the idea of imitation and 'speech' in the chimpanzee. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

column3: Le suicide: essai d'�tude psychanalytique
column6: Apparently, suicide is a rapturous gesture, stemming from oral regression which results from genetic or constitutional weaknesses, and involves the loss of a love-object. The trend originates early, when oscillations of excitation-inhibition fail to become integrated during the process of language formation. Furthermore, in some cases, these excitable impulses substitute for language. Therefore, a linguistic attack appears promising. Moreover, during psychoanalysis, therapy is enhanced by the communion between the unconscious of patient and analyst. 4 case studies. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

column3: Novoe uchenie o yazyke i dialekticheskiy materializm
column6: Marr's new theory of language and thinking is in complete agreement with dialectic materialism. Language developed from gestures. Sign language originated as a woman's language in matriarchal civilizations and depended on the role of the hand as a primitive tool. Language and thinking were one, but gradually the tool became cause and the product effect, so that language became a form of thinking and thinking the content of language. General and abstract ideas first occurred when sound-language developed and artificial tools were used. The polysemantic word gradually is split into two which express opposite ideas (in Armenian the same word is used for soul as for body).
